Divergences

Feeling closer in different ways
Romain Girard

I currently work as a data scientist at Implicity, where I develop machine learning techniques to study strokes and heart failure.

I am strongly interested in both data science for healthcare and theoretical machine learning.

I graduated in 2018 from École polytechnique, Paris.

I hold a M.Sc. degree from the MVA (Mathématiques, Vision, Apprentissage) master at ENS Paris-Saclay, with an emphasis on machine learning and statistics.

Contact me

Multi-Scale DenseNet, a resource-aware CNN

Real-world applications require models to adapt to limited computational budgets. MSDNets enable feature re-use and early classification to preserve accuracy with low resources.

Multi-Scale Dense Networks for resource efficient image classification, Huang et al., 2018


2018, Sep 24   —  21 minute read # ICLR 2018 # Resource efficiency # CNN

Neural Machine Translation of the Cambridge meme

State-of-the-art NMT systems can't cope with even moderate amounts of noise, especially human mistakes. It is time to call for more robust models, and more realistic noise synthesis.

Synthetic and natural noise both break Neural Machine Translation, Belinkov et al., 2018


2018, Sep 10   —  16 minute read # ICLR 2018 # Neural Machine Translation # Noise

The Gini coefficient is not the best inequality metric

Simple and widely used, the Gini coefficient is a popular inequality metric. However, it exhibits undesirable behavior, and better alternatives exist, such as the generalized entropy indices.


2018, Aug 21   —  1 minute read # Miscellaneous # Econometrics # Inequality

Adam's convergence proof is flawed

Adam, a popular optimization algorithm in deep learning, does not correctly converge in all convex settings. This is linked to the learning rate that is wrongly assumed to be non-increasing.

On the convergence of Adam and beyond, Reddi et al., 2018


2018, Aug 19   —  10 minute read # ICLR 2018 # Adam # Optimization
